title: 111_hr2991
content:
The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, or performance bonds by an eligible small business concern. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety for small businesses needing bonds to bid on contracts, serve as contractors, or subcontractors. The guarantee is provided when the person cannot obtain the bond on reasonable terms without it, and there is a reasonable expectation of performance. The surety is indemnified against loss from avoiding bonds. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against loss in avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, subject to certain conditions. This includes the Secretary determining an imminent breach, requiring approval before payments, and no payments without Secretary's consent. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against loss in avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, with payments not exceeding 10% of the contract price unless deemed necessary by the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary shall not pay the surety an amount exceeding the guaranteed share of the bond available. Any guarantee or agreement to indemnify obligates the Secretary to reimburse the surety a specified sum. The Secretary may reimburse the surety for up to 90% of the loss incurred, with an exception for fraud or misrepresentation in obtaining the guarantee or reimbursement. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties to meet standards for underwriting, claim practices, and loss ratios. The Secretary may also adopt a procedure for reimbursing sureties for paid losses based on prior monthly payments. The Secretary requires participating sureties to make reports and allows audits of their documents and records every three years. The Secretary mandates audits every three years by approved examiners. Administrative provisions include establishing fees for small businesses and sureties. A state program may be implemented in up to 5 states with allocated funds. The Secretary oversees guarantee issuance and surety assistance for small businesses. States in the program must meet prescribed assessments and standards. Selected states must submit annual reports on their administered programs. The Secretary administers guarantee issuance and surety assistance for small businesses. An annual report must be submitted detailing the program's implementation, number of sureties receiving guarantees, states involved, and participation of eligible small business concerns. The annual report must include details on the program's implementation, number of sureties receiving guarantees, states involved, and participation of eligible small business concerns. Definitions for "bid bond" and "eligible small business concern" apply in this subsection. The term 'eligible small business concern' refers to a small business owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, service-disabled veterans, or qualified HUBZone small business concerns. The term 'obligee' refers to the person requesting bids for a contract in the case of a bid bond, or the person who has contracted with a principal for the completion of a contract in the case of a payment bond or performance bond. The terms related to bonds in a contract include payment bond (for money payment to contracted persons), performance bond (for contract completion), prime contractor (contract performer), and principal (contract party). The term 'principal' refers to a person who is bidding for a contract or is primarily responsible for completing a contract. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Transportation. The term 'subcontractor' is also defined. The term 'surety' refers to a person or State that provides financial guarantees in the event of contract breaches, including bid bonds, performance bonds, and payment bonds. The term 'surety' refers to a person or State that provides financial guarantees in the event of contract breaches. A payment bond ensures payment to all labor and material suppliers if the principal fails to pay promptly. Authorization of appropriations is set at $50,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2010 through 2014. SEC. 3. NATIONAL INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE.

Amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code to include "any Federal, State, or local mode of transportation".

SEC. 4. PROVISION OF RELEVANT INFORMATION.

Amends Section 332(d) of title 49, United States Code by removing references to specific entities.
